title: Sales flak but toilet-maker GWA aims for flat earnings outlook
text:
Actual sales were up 17 per cent for the quarter, which includes the boost from a recent company acquisition.

Mr Salt told The Australian Financial Review the underlying sales dip could be linked to slowdowns in new housing building and existing housing turnover, which impacts GWA’s renovation products.

“That domestic piece is slow at the moment,” he said. “The flip side is commercial is very robust, particularly in NSW and in Victoria.”

Commercial work ranges from tap and toilet systems for offices to aged care.

Mr Salt added rising housing prices and auction turnovers in Sydney and Melbourne was positive, but unlikely to boost GWA sales until late in the financial year.

“We think there's some early green shoots coming out,” he said.

The company forecast normalised earnings before interest and tax for the first half would be between $37 million and $41 million. For the full year this figure, which strips out significant items, was tipped at between $80 million and $85 million.

That includes the boost from Methven, a New Zealand-based taps and showers specialist that GWA bought in April this year. Mr Salt said the comparative figure for last year would be $83 million.

Advertisement

He argued this would be a “great” result in a shrinking market. “We're very much ... thinking the second half will be stronger than the first half, more as a result of what we're doing rather than necessarily what the market’s doing,” he said.

Changes included focusing on costs. Mr Salt said they had been able to source some cheaper providers of certain goods in countries such as Vietnam, and Chinese suppliers were also dropping prices because of the impact of trade tensions with the US.

Job numbers were about 850, and he said GWA would look to natural attrition rather than engage on big employee redundancies.

The meeting passed smoothly with investors heavily backing resolutions.

Institutional Shareholder Services, which advises big investors on resolution voting, backed GWA’s remuneration structures overall, saying pay and performance was reasonably aligned.

That was despite some ISS concerns about Mr Salt’s fixed pay, at $967,000 last year, being above industry averages.

It also queried one measure – return on funds employed – being applied to short and long-term bonuses “meaning the company may be paying incentives to executives twice for the same performance”.
description: “It is challenging out there,” says the maker of kitchen and toilet fittings.
